question: Baldwin Corporation began the year with cash of $35,000 and a computer that cost $20,000. During the year Baldwin earned sales revenue of $140,000 and had the following expenses: salaries, $59,000; rent, $8,000; and utilities, $3,000. At year end Baldwin's cash balance was down to $16,000. How much net income (or net loss) did Baldwin experience for the year?

Accounting does not provide information that is useful in making decisions that have economic consequences.

Cash basis considers the revenue as realized when the goods are produced.
Journal means recording the business transactions in the journal.

Temporary accounts because they are used only to compute the net income for the accounting period.
Capital at the end — net profit + drawings = Capital in the beginning.
If a profit agreement is made but a loss agreement is not, a loss is allocated in the same way as a profit.

The term cost refers to the amount at which a transaction is recorded.
If a transaction causes total asset of the company to increase by $2,000, then liabilities plus stockholders’ equity also increases by $2,000.
Liability accounts increase with a debit and decrease with a credit.
Balance Sheet is a statement of the financial position of an enterprise at a given date.
A cost is recorded as an expense when the company acquires an economic resource providing future benefits.

Depreciation is the Decrease in the value of current assets.
Expenses are the prices charged to a company’s customers for goods or services provided during a particular time period.
Depreciation is charged on all fixed assets except buildings.

In cash basis accounting, revenue and expense transactions are recorded in the accounting period when the goods or services are provided, regardless of whether cash is received or paid by the company.
A Ledger provides a chronological record of all transactions affecting a firm.
Journal is the first book of original entry in which all transactions are recorded.
All liabilities which become due for payment in one year are classified as long term liabilities.
An accounting period is the period of time for which the revenues and expenses of a company are computed.
Paying employees' salaries for the current period is recorded with a debit to Salaries Expense.
Providing services to customers on account causes assets to increase and owner' equity to increase.
A partnership is an association of one or more persons to carry on as co-owners a business for profit.
Assets and owner's equity are presented on the right side of the balance sheet.
It is sometimes difficult to determine if a partnership does in fact exist.
Corporations are the most important form of business ownership because they conduct the vast majority of business.
After recording each transaction, total assets must equal total liabilities plus stockholders' equity.
The partners of a partnership may be able to operate with more flexibility because they are not subject to the control of a board of directors.

Internal transactions are events that affect the financial position of the company but do not include an exchange with a separate economic entity. Examples are using supplies on hand and earning revenues after having received cash in advance from a customer.
There may be certain tax advantages to a partnership, because a partnership is taxed as a separate entity.
Borrowing cash from the bank causes assets to increase and liabilities to increase.
A loan from a financial institution will increase assets and increase liabilities.
Providing services to customers for cash causes stockholders' equity to increase.
For each transaction, the total debit amounts must equal the total credit amounts.
Purchasing office supplies on account causes assets to increase and liabilities to increase.
An audit is an examination of transactions and financial statements.
Receiving cash in advance from a customer for services to be provided in the future causes assets to increase and owner's equity to increase.
Amounts owed from customers are recorded in the Accounts Receivable account.
If expenses are more than revenues, the resulting negative amount is called net loss, instead of net income.
Matching principle states that expenses of an accounting period are subtracted from the revenues earned during that period to determine net income.
For financial accounting, a company usually uses a calendar year as its accounting period.
An account is a summary record of the changes in a particular asset, liability, or owner's equity.
A credit to an account balance always results in the balance decreasing.
A capital interest in a partnership can't be sold or disposed of in any way.
Paying employees' salaries for the current month causes no change to stockholders' equity.
Liability accounts increase with a credit and decrease with a debit.

For each transaction, there must be at least one debit amount and one credit amount.
Borrowing cash from the bank is recorded with a debit to cash.
The general ledger includes all accounts used to record the company's transactions.
After posting transactions to the general ledger accounts, the sum of the accounts with debit balances should equal the sum of the accounts with credit balances.
If total debits equal total credits in the trial balance, then all balances are correct.
A sole proprietorship is an accounting entity, even though it has only a single owner.
Examples of assets include cash, inventory, and capital stock issued to investors.
Expenses are the costs of providing the goods or services during the time period.

Purchasing supplies on account increases the balance of the Accounts Receivable account.
A debit to an account balance always results in the balance increasing.
Managerial accounting serves external users while financial accounting serves internal users.
Revenue accounts are increased by debit entries and decreased by credit entries.
The balance sheet equation is assets = liabilities - owner's equity.
Buying or selling on credit creates an accounts payable or receivable.
Net income = Assets - Liabilities.
Net Profit: The excess of expenses over revenue during a particular accounting period.
A journal provides a chronological record of all transactions affecting a firm.

External transactions are transactions the firm conducts with a separate economic entity, such as selling products to a customer, purchasing supplies from a vendor, paying salaries to an employee, and borrowing money from a bank.
A cost is recorded as an asset if it results from providing goods or services to customers.
Purchasing equipment using cash causes assets to increase.

Paying rent expense for the current month causes no change to stockholders' equity.
The going concern concept considers the business and the proprietor as distinct from each other.
In a limited partnership, one or more of the partners must be a general partner.
In sole proprietorships and partnerships, the business and the owner(s) are not legally separate entities.
After recording each transaction, total revenues must equal total expenses.
The accounts relating to income, expenses, losses, and gains are classified as real accounts.
A decrease in value of a fixed asset due to age, wear and tear is known as accumulated depreciation.
A general partner has unlimited liability for the partnership debts.
The nominal account records all the transactions of a business for one fiscal year.
Salaries authorized for each partner and interest on capital investments are reported as expenses.
If an investment is made in the partnership, the net assets and total capital of the firm are increased.
A general partner has unlimited liability for the partnership debts.
Preparation of partnership agreement in writing is voluntary.
In a general partnership, form each partner is personally liable for the obligations of the partnership.
A written agreement is necessary to form a partnership.
One of the major advantages of a partnership is that it permits the pooling of both capital resources and the multiple skills of the individual partners.
For accounting purposes, a partnership is a separate business entity.
In a limited partnership, one or more of the partners must be a general partner.
Normally, every partner act as an agent for the partnership and for every other partner.
Generally, a partnership subject to as much governmental regulations.
The capital account of each partner is debited when assets are invested in the partnership by that person.
If a transaction causes total asset of the company to increase by $5,000 and total liabilities to increase by $3,000, then stockholders' equity increases by $2,000.
Book-keeping is a part of accounting and is concerned with the recording of transactions which is often routine and clerical in nature.
Providing services to customers is recorded with a debit to Service Revenue.
Management accounting is meant to help in decision-making by analyzing and interpreting the information generated by financial accounting.
Purchasing office supplies is recorded with a credit to office supplies.
The process of transferring the debit and credit information from the journal to individual accounts in the general ledger is called journalizing.
A trial balance is a list of all accounts and their balances at a particular date, showing that assets equal liabilities.
Within the income statement are two sections: (1) Revenues (2) Expenses.
In accrual accounting, the net income for the accounting period is computed by subtracting the cash payments from the cash receipts for operations.
Goodwill is classified as intangible asset on the balance sheet.

In the absence of an agreement or if the partners are unable to reach an agreement, the law provides that profits are to be divided equally.
